threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14218912
You are defining purpose as having an onus to perform an action right? I don't believe there's anyone out there that denies the existence of that. I breathe right now because my biological impulses compel me to do so. You would say that my purpose for breathing is those same biological impulses. I don't think anyone has any objection to that statement. The fundamental difference in that scenario would be how we interpret "life has no meaning". If you boil purpose and meaning down to "you have an onus to do something" then you're absolutely correct in saying anyone continuing to breathe has it. Anything denying that is absolutely insane because it's demonstrable by anyone doing anything ever. But no one is denying that in the first place.
To elaborate on my point about a relativistic view on purpose and meaning (ex: we create our own "purpose" and "meaning") being pragmatically identical to nihilism - compare it to an "objective" purpose or meaning.
Objective meaning:
>You/everyone HAS a purpose or meaning that you are supposed to fulfill
>You ought to alter your behavior to fit it
Relativistic meaning:
>You/everyone creates their own "meaning" and "reason for living" based on their own desires
>Does not necessarily need to alter behavior to achieve purpose/meaning, can simply decide on a different one
Nihilism:
>Does not believe in objective meaning and rejects the idea that they need a personal meaning
>Does not need to alter behavior

threads.sub: How bad was rural living during the early modern era?
threads.com:
I homestead myself, and after doing it for sometime I think rural living, especially pre-industrialization, is portrayed poorly. It has its issues for sure, but its far and away much better than urban living or living in a suburb. Most of the complaints I see about it are:
>Theres not much to do
Which is why you need to take up a hobby. Homebrewing, whittling, wood work, gardening, studying history/languages, reading, archery, HEMA. Theres no hand holding, you just do it.
>Its more work
Kind of. It has bouts of busy work that eat up your day and then days or even weeks of doing nothing but twiddling your thumbs aside from the most basic of chores. Its better than spending 10+ hours at the office/commuting and then sleeping.

threads.com:
Lviv, Ukraine was host to a savage outbreak of anti-Semitic violence during the initial weeks of Operation Barbarossa in summer 1941. The radical Ukrainian nationalist organization OUN collaborated with the German occupation forces to launch a reign of terror on Lviv's Jews. On July 1, Jews were dragged from their homes into the streets where they were taunted, assaulted, and accused of collaboration with Bolshevism. Jewish women were stripped to their undergarments or completely naked and paraded through the streets.

German forces took control and suppressed the rioting the next day. The Einsatzgruppen went to work rounding up and shooting Jews en masse. At least 2,000 perished during the first week of July. Remaining Jews were herded into a ghetto where they were systematically exterminated over the next three years. A total of 120,000 Jews were sent to the Belczec concentration camp or killed locally. Virtually none were left by the time the Red Army liberated Lviv in July 1944. The modern state of Ukraine has paid little attention to the massacre; the city today is nearly all ethnic Ukrainians following the war and removal of Jews and ethnic Poles and the historical presence of both groups in Lviv is not generally acknowledged.

One of the leaders of OUN, Yaroslav Stetsko, went into exile in West Germany after the war where he formed an anti-Soviet organization called the Anti-Bolshevik Bloc of Nations. Stetsko suffered no punishment or war crimes charges for his part in the massacre; he was invited to the White House in 1983 where President Reagan called him "the last premier of free Ukraine." Stetsko passed away in Munich three years later at the age of 74.

last_replies.com: >One can find a precursor to the Lviv Massacre in the pogrom of Strasbourg almost 600 years earlier. On Valentine's Day 1349, the Jews of the imperial city were rounded up and burned en masse after lobbying by the butcher's guild of the city, who apparently believed Jewish butchers were unfairly undercutting them on meat prices because the latter had a practice of selling to Gentiles at discounts parts of slaughtered animals deemed unsuitable for kosher use. The Jewish community of Strasbourg was marched out to the town square, stripped naked, and robbed of any money or valuables they were carrying. A handful converted to Christianity and were spared from execution. Some of the more attractive Jewish women as well as a number of children were spared from burning and involuntarily baptized. It is recorded that at least one woman was saved from the flames by a wealthy citizen of Strasbourg, baptized, and sent to a convent in the Rhine River Valley where he provided her a stipend to live on. It may also be that many of the victims were hanged or beheaded to spare them the agony of roasting alive. Although contemporary accounts speak of 2,000 Jews burned, this may be an exaggeration as it is not believed that the Jewish population of Strasbourg at this time was greater than 300.[9]

threads.com: I currently believe no religion is the ultimate truth. But, i like the idea and i do believe in it that all religions lead somewhere. Hinduism leads to Moksha, Buddhism to Nirvana, Judaism, Islam and Christianity to paradise, and so on. So i believe in that. But, I'm unsure about the negative afterlives of them. And, i think one ought to have something to hold on to. So i believe in a nature spirit, a spirit of the universe if you will. And in meditation. That's central. Once i meditated enough i will experience ultimate bliss, and while eastern religions also promise great bliss, they're just not for me. I can't meditate on a mantra or watch my breath or whatever, i have my own technique and frankly i don't want to abandon either celibacy or eating onions and garlic (forbidden in Mahayana Buddhism) or, live with a heavenly spouse as Hinduism promises and have a house. If i could choose, i would live either in some heaven or on earth as a wandering ascetic forever, i think. Just meditation and belief in this nature spirit guiding me. I started to feel the negative aspects of living in a home. I don't think there's a heavenly abode where you wander from place to place forever. So I'm a perennialist. I thought about Judaism being close to my beliefs but even that has a dogmatic approach to it and i think i can reach total tranquility by meditation not by waiting for the shekinah. Tell me what you think of my short paragraph if you want. Thanks for reading.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14218605
>What is it called when someone tries to refute a broad statement or notion with something minor, as if the something minor refutes the entire statement?

First post got it: >>14218634
It's called Anecdotal or Anecdotal Evidence like they said. It's the idea that somebody will bring up an exception or something they witnessed and now suddenly the expectation is that one thing needs to be addressed because it somehow debunks or disqualifies everything else. It's kind of similar to "What about'isms" where someone will literally say, "Well what about THIS?" and then it's almost assuredly some stupid fucking bullshit meant to derail the discussion.

The second example you gave is maybe more of this: >>14218652 just a false/vague generalization.

Regardless, they're both ways of *trying* to arguing against something when you don't actually know what the fuck the other guy is talking about because if you did you'd refute their points instead of bringing up random bullshit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>14218659
That's not exception proving the rule. Exception proving the rule would be if only an exception is listed, thus showing that there is indeed a rule. Such as a sign that says that parking is allowed here on Thursdays, 7:00 A.M. to 2:00 P.M. The rule would be no parking. But since there is no sign that says no parking, just the exception, it's the exception that proves the rule.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Oriental and Eastern Orthodoxy are similar aesthetically but doctrinally there are differences, particularly when it comes to the "nature" of Christ. In recent years the Catholic Church has tried to downplay the differences with Miaphysites (OO) but for EO it's technically a big deal. During EO liturgy (mass), the priest uses two candle stands to bless the congregation: "The dikirion holds two candles, representing the dual nature of Jesus (divine and human), and the trikirion holds three, representing the three persons of the Holy Trinity."

As for Catholicism, yes, there were a bunch of changes made to it during the High Middle Ages that completely warped how it became. They started making nude portraits and statues of saints, prophets and God himself. Orthodox sects don't make nude depictions of any of them, and don't depict the "Holy Father" in general in human form, only Jesus. Catholicism adopted purgatory and limbo as doctrine which other sects of Christianity in general do not have, only mainstream Islam has them.

Hi /his/ I have an humanities question for you; a zoomer (15) I know from discord asked me to teach him "computer science" (calculus, set theory, graphs, complexity, etc.) I have been teaching him for 4 months and he is progressing twice or thrice as fast as I did in college. I know for a fact that he isn't particularly intelligent, he often struggles a little with the more math-heavy bits, but it surprised me how quickly he can understand and "visualize" new concepts, and he has no problem with things like formal demonstrations.

I attributed this to brain plasticity, which got me thinking: the time range covered by high-school (15-18) seems to be a rare stage where your brain is mature enough to have interests and understand complex ideas, but still young enough to adapt to new concepts.

Why is this golden window of pedagogy wasted on high-schools that basically function as daycare centers for teenagers? Depending on the country, it occupies 40% to 70% of the students' waking-hours between commute, classes, and homework (busywork). What would be the arguments against a 3-year middle-school diploma required for jobs, and optional, domain-specific high-schools with 4-year courses diplomas (bachelor's degree equivalent)?

I can't be the first one that notices this.

threads.com:
The Lokot Autonomy (Russian: Лóкoтcкoe caмoyпpaвлéниe, lit.'Lókotskoye samoupravléniye') or Lokot Republic (Russian: Лóкoтcкaя pecпyбликa, lit.'Lókotskaya respublika', German: Republik Lokot) was an autonomous structure on the territory of the Central Russian oblasts of Bryansk, Oryol and Kursk from July 1942 to August 1943.[3]

The Wehrmacht entered the area in October 1941 and were forced out in August 1943.[3] The autonomy was formed in July 1942, when six districts were added to the Lokot district.[3] The autonomy's name was derived from the region's administrative center, the urban-type settlement of Lokot in Oryol Oblast (now located in Bryansk Oblast). The "Autonomy" covered the area of eight raions (the present-day Brasovsky, Dmitriyevsky, Dmitrovsky, Komarichsky, Navlinsky, Sevsky, Suzemsky and Zheleznogorsky districts) now divided between Bryansk, Oryol and Kursk Oblasts.[4]

Instead of being ruled by the German military administration, the Lokot Autonomy was ruled by a Russian civil administration of Bronislav Kaminski and Konstantin Voskoboinik [fr].[3] The German authorities established the Autonomy to serve as a test case for a Russian collaborationist government under the SS in the proposed Reichskommissariat Moskowien.[5]

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
In the landmark case of Furman v. Georgia (1972) the Supreme Court ordered states to suspend the use of capital punishment until sentencing guidelines were improved upon. The case originated when a mentally disturbed black man named William Furman committed a home invasion in Savannah, Georgia in 1967. Although his intent had merely been to rob, he accidentally shot the owner of the home while fleeing, resulting in his death. Furman was charged with 1st degree murder and sentenced to death after a one day trial.

The Court consolidated Furman with two other cases, Jackson v. Georgia and Branch v. Texas, and in a contentious ruling voted 5-4 that capital punishment as currently used by the states infringed on the 8th and 14th Amendments. No proper opinion was written concerning the case, merely a one paragraph summary about the death penalty's non-constitutionality. Justices Douglas, Stewart, and Brennan wrote that death penalty statutes were applied "arbitrarily" and often showed a strong racial bias against black men, particularly in the South. Such deliberate racial bias would violate the Equal Protection Clause, however, Stewart wrote that racial bias in sentencing could not be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. Instead he argued that the arbitrary use of capital punishment was injust and immoral.

Justices Brennan and Marshall believed capital punishment was a vestige of a ruder time and did not belong in the more enlightened modern age. The latter also felt that it was too likely for innocent persons to be wrongfully executed.
